importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Diwali is celebrated on this date, marking the festival of lights and serving as a cultural and spiritual milestone for millions globally.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The five-day Diwali festival spans from October 20 to October 25, creating a period of cultural, religious, and community celebration across South Asia and diaspora communities worldwide.

keyTakeAways: Diwali is a major festival celebrated by over a billion Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists, marking the triumph of light over darkness and good over evil.
The festival occurs annually in autumn, typically between October and November, with the main celebration on the third day.

Diwali has both religious and cultural significance, with different regional and faith-based interpretations, such as the return of Rama and Sita, the defeat of Narakasura, and the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings.
Celebrations include lighting diyas, decorating homes with rangolis, feasting, exchanging gifts, and performing rituals like Lakshmi Puja and Bhai Dooj.
Diwali is not only a religious event but also a cultural festival celebrated by people of many faiths and backgrounds, reflecting its role in fostering community and unity.
In Sikh tradition, Diwali is observed as 'Bandi Chhor Divas' — the day of liberation when Guru Hargobind and 52 Hindu kings were freed from imprisonment.
For Jains, Diwali commemorates the attainment of enlightenment by Lord Mahavira; for some Buddhists, it marks Emperor Ashoka's embrace of Buddhism.
In India, Diwali marks the start of the new financial year and is a time when businesses open new accounts.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Diwali, also known as Deepavali, is a major cultural and religious festival celebrated by over a billion Hindus, Sikhs, Jains, and Buddhists worldwide, primarily on October 20, 2025. The festival symbolizes the triumph of light over darkness and good over evil, with diverse religious narratives including the return of Rama and Sita, the defeat of demon kings like Narakasura and Bali, and the liberation of Guru Hargobind and 52 kings. It is observed over five days, each with unique traditions: Dhanteras (purchase of gold and silver), Choti Diwali (Krishna's victory), Diwali (Lakshmi Puja and family feasting), Padwa (husband-wife bond), and Bhai Dooj (sibling love). Celebrations include lighting diyas, setting off fireworks, decorating homes with rangoli, and exchanging gifts. Diwali transcends religious boundaries, becoming a global cultural celebration of community, renewal, and hope, especially in South Asia and among diasporas in countries like Malaysia, Fiji, and Nepal.
title: It’s Diwali, a time for light, community and fresh starts
